comment.author: 64555638@N00
comment._content: From left to right: Frida Kahlo, Peig Sayers, Michael D.

comment.author: 64564846@N07
comment._content: Now there's you a real motley crew!

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/64555638@N00] and there's Merle Streep beside him!!!  What a wonderful social commentary Carol, great shot and great material to mull over with a nice cup of tea and (non virtual) sticky bun!  The two ladies with veils over their faces as a reminder that the hijab was not the only form of face covering in use.  The gentleman with the top hat looking so discomfited by mixing with the hoi-polloi and the casual boater relaxing at the back, a great start to a Flickr week!

comment.author: 64555638@N00
comment._content: I'd say the woman at far left is only going as far as the Spanish Arch.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/eyelightfilms] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie] You're both very pass remarkable today!  :)  What do you reckon to the veils though? Dust? Widowhood? Modesty?

And [http://www.flickr.com/photos/eyelightfilms] why only to the Spanish Arch?!

comment.author: 64555638@N00
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] Spanish Arch because she looks quite Spanish in that veil. It's much more decorative than the others.
I'd say the veils are primarily to keep dust out, but knowing Galway, I'd be more worried about the rain.

comment.author: 14302637@N08
comment._content: There is an engraving from the Illustrated London News, 29th Nov 1879. www.prints-4-u.com/store/image2/P1751879/P1751879500.jpg "Kilkenny & Thurles Royal Mail and Day Car" outside P.Fitzpatrick, Grocer. I don't know of any other country that had Day Cars and Side Cars with the fold-down foot rests.

comment.author: 30687643@N00
comment._content: maps.google.com/maps?q=Eyre+Square,+The+Docks,+Galway,+Ir... think this is near the spot

comment.author: 14302637@N08
comment._content: Here is the Birds Eye View of Rosemary Avenue binged.it/wEU2wT The gaudy building was Woolworths, built on the site of Black's Royal Hotel. In a few years time, children will ask "what's Woolworths?" Historic OSI map maps.osi.ie/publicviewer/#V1,529915,725450,7,9

comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/blackpoolbeach] Really? So they were unique to Ireland, then?

comment.author: 14302637@N08
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] I read a library book a few years ago all about Irish horse-drawn carriages. The "Side Car" had 2 wheels and one horse. catalogue.nli.ie/Record/vtls000168473/Image?lookfor=http:... It looks like the nearest today is in County Mayo. db.museumsofmayo.com/WebX?50@201.Res7htUVFem.0@.3b9db301 There is a taxi rank of "Side Cars" waiting for customers outside the Adelphi Hotel. www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland/6797347614 The "Day Car" had 4 wheels and 2 horses as used by Royal Mail. I am sure the fold-down foot rests are unique to Ireland. Google gives very few results.

comment.author: 14302637@N08
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] It's all coming back slowly in my memory. The book was about Charles Bianconi who founded a network of public transport in Ireland. It might have been "Bianconi: King of the Irish roads", publisher Allen Figis 1962 Authors Molly O'Connell Bianconi and Col. Sydney John Watson en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charles_Bianconi

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/blackpoolbeach] See, that lie down in a dark room that our bell photo drove you to, has worked wonders for your memory!  :)
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons
